title: Journalism — The Five W's of News Reporting
description: Students explore the structure of news articles by learning the five W's: Who, What, When, Where, and Why. They analyze a real news story and identify each element.
instructions:
1. Show the child a printed or digital news article written for children.
2. Read the article together.
3. Introduce the five W's chart: Who, What, When, Where, Why.
4. Work through the article together, identifying each W.
5. Discuss why these questions matter — they give readers the most important information first.
6. Have the child fill in a Five W's graphic organizer for a second article independently.

slides.heading: Journalism
slides.subheading: The Five W's of News Reporting
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page of our adventure! It's called "Journalism" and it tells us we're going to become super news detectives, learning about the "Five W's of News Reporting." It's like learning the secret code that reporters use to tell us all the important stuff about what's happening!

slides.setup_instructions: Print 2-3 short news articles from a children's news source (e.g., Newsela, Time for Kids). Prepare a Five W's chart with columns: Who, What, When, Where, Why.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the tools we'll need for our detective work! We've got a couple of news stories that are just for kids, a special chart with the Five W's to fill in, some colorful highlighters, and a notebook. You'll need a grown-up to help you find and print those news stories and the chart, but then we'll use our pencils and highlighters to find all the clues!

slides.text: Ask the child: 'Have you ever read a newspaper or watched the news? What do reporters do?' Discuss how journalists share true stories about events happening in the world.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we start thinking like real reporters! Imagine you're watching the news or reading a newspaper – what are the reporters doing? They're telling us stories about things that really happened, right? Our job is to understand how they share those stories so we get all the important details.

slides.text: Read the first article aloud together. Then introduce the Five W's: 'Every good news story answers five important questions. We call them the Five W's.' Write them on the board: Who? What? When? Where? Why?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read our first news story together! After we read it, I'll introduce you to the Five W's: Who, What, When, Where, and Why. These are the super important questions that every good news story answers to tell us everything we need to know.

slides.text: Go back through the article. Assign each W a highlight color. Highlight the WHO (people involved), WHAT (what happened), WHEN (time), WHERE (place), and WHY (reason or cause).
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where the fun highlighting comes in! We'll go back through the story we just read and use a different color for each of the Five W's. We'll find the people (Who), what happened (What), when it happened (When), where it happened (Where), and why it happened (Why) and color them in!

slides.text: Show that most news articles put the most important information in the very first paragraph — this is called the 'lead.' The lead usually answers most of the Five W's right away.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this part of the article? It's called the "lead," and it's like the most important sentence or two at the very beginning. Good reporters put all the most exciting and important information in the lead so you know the main story right away, usually answering most of our Five W's!

slides.prompt: Read the second article independently. Use your graphic organizer to identify all Five W's. Can you find them all? Which W's appear in the first paragraph?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the detective! You'll read this second story all by yourself and use your graphic organizer to find all the Who, What, When, Where, and Why clues. See if you can find them all, and pay extra attention to which W's you find right at the very beginning of the story!

slides.text: Share your Five W's findings. Compare how different articles organize information. Tomorrow you'll start writing your own news articles!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify all five W's in a news article and explain why the lead paragraph is important?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You found all the Five W's in that second article and filled out your organizer! We discovered how different stories tell us things in different ways, and you're getting so good at spotting the most important details. Tomorrow, we'll even get to try writing our own news stories!

parent_notes: Children's news sources like Time for Kids, Newsela, or DOGOnews provide age-appropriate articles. Choose stories about animals, science discoveries, or community events rather than distressing topics. The Five W's framework is a powerful tool not just for journalism but for all informational writing. Encourage the child to notice news articles in everyday life — even sports reporting uses the Five W's.

title: Data and Graphing — Reading Bar Graphs
description: Students learn to read and interpret bar graphs, extracting information to answer questions about data sets. They practice comparing quantities using vertical and horizontal bar graphs.
instructions:
1. Show the child a simple bar graph (e.g., 'Favorite Fruits in Our Class').
2. Identify the parts: title, x-axis (categories), y-axis (numbers), bars.
3. Model how to read values by tracing from bar top to the y-axis.
4. Ask comparison questions: 'Which has the most? The least? How many more?'
5. Provide 2-3 additional bar graphs for independent practice.
6. Introduce horizontal bar graphs and compare to vertical.

slides.heading: Data and Graphing
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of a book, telling us what we're going to learn about! We're going to become super detectives who can read special charts called bar graphs and understand all the cool information they show us.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 4-5 bar graphs at varying difficulty levels. Create a set of 3-4 questions per graph (e.g., 'Which category has the highest value? What is the difference between X and Y?').
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our tools ready for some graphing fun! We need some printed bar graphs to look at, a ruler to help us measure, a pencil for writing, graph paper for drawing later, colored pencils to make things pretty, and a worksheet with questions for each graph. Go ask a grown-up to help you find all these things!

slides.text: Show the first bar graph. Say: 'A bar graph is a way to show information using bars. Each bar represents a category, and the height tells us how much or how many.' Point to the title: 'The title tells us what the graph is about.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This first bar graph is like a picture story of information. See the title at the top? That tells us what the story is about! The bars are like little buildings, and how tall they are shows us how much of something there is.

slides.text: Identify each part together: the title, the labels on the bottom (categories), the numbers on the side (scale), and the bars themselves. Use a ruler to trace from the top of each bar across to read the exact value.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's be super sleuths and figure out what each part of this graph tells us. We'll look at the title, the labels at the bottom that tell us what we're counting, and the numbers on the side that tell us how many. Then, we'll use our ruler to carefully go from the top of each bar straight over to the number so we know exactly how much it represents.

slides.text: Ask questions: 'Which category has the tallest bar? What value does it show? Which has the shortest? What is the difference between the tallest and shortest?' Write out the subtraction to find differences.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we become math wizards! We'll look at our graph and find the tallest bar – that one shows us the most of something. Then we'll find the shortest bar for the least. To find out how much more one thing has than another, we'll do a little subtraction, just like you've learned!

slides.text: Show a horizontal bar graph. Discuss: 'This shows the same kind of information, but the bars go sideways. Now the categories are on the side and the numbers are on the bottom.' Practice reading it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is another way to show the same kind of information, but the bars are lying down! Instead of categories on the bottom, they are on the side now, and the numbers are on the bottom. It's like looking at the graph from a different angle, but we can still read it the same way to find out what's what.

slides.prompt: Read each bar graph and answer the questions on your worksheet. For each graph: identify the highest and lowest categories, calculate differences between bars, and write one observation in a complete sentence.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the graph expert! For each graph on your paper, read the bars carefully and answer the questions on your worksheet. Find the biggest and smallest amounts, figure out the differences, and write down one interesting thing you notice about the graph. You've got this!

slides.text: Review answers together. Discuss: 'Why are bar graphs useful? When would someone use a bar graph instead of just listing numbers?' Tomorrow we'll create our own bar graphs!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately read values from both vertical and horizontal bar graphs and calculate differences between categories?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did an amazing job reading all those graphs! We learned how to find the most and least, and even how to figure out the difference between amounts, all by looking at those colorful bars. It's like you unlocked a secret code to understand information, and that's super useful for lots of things!

parent_notes: Bar graphs are a foundational data literacy skill. Start with graphs that use round numbers (increments of 1, 2, 5, or 10) before moving to more complex scales. Real-world examples are everywhere — cereal boxes, magazines, websites. Encourage the child to find bar graphs in daily life. The key skills here are reading exact values and making comparisons (more than, less than, difference).

title: The Industrial Revolution — From Farm to Factory
description: Students explore the dramatic shift from agricultural life to factory-based manufacturing during the Industrial Revolution, understanding how inventions changed the way people lived and worked.
instructions:
1. Review the timeline: place the Industrial Revolution (late 1700s-1800s) after the Enlightenment.
2. Discuss life before factories: most people farmed, made goods by hand, lived in small villages.
3. Introduce the concept of a factory: many workers making products with machines.
4. Discuss key inventions: spinning jenny, water frame, power loom.
5. Compare before-and-after: how long it took to make cloth by hand vs. by machine.
6. Create a timeline entry and illustrate the transformation.
materials_needed: Pictures of pre-industrial life and early factories

slides.heading: The Industrial Revolution
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our big adventure! It's called "The Industrial Revolution," and it tells us how things went "From Farm to Factory," meaning how people stopped doing most things on farms and started making lots of things in big buildings called factories. It's going to be super interesting to see how much life changed!

items: Pictures of pre-industrial and industrial life
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare pictures showing village life vs. factory life. Have cotton balls or wool samples to touch. Set up the timeline to show where the Industrial Revolution falls.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this part, we need some cool stuff to help us learn! We've got a timeline to see where this big change happened, pictures showing what life was like way back then, and even some real cotton or wool so you can feel what people used before machines. You'll also need drawing paper and colored pencils to make your own pictures and index cards for notes. Go grab all these things with a grown-up's help!

slides.text: Review the timeline together: 'We've studied the Renaissance, the Age of Exploration, the Scientific Revolution, and the Enlightenment. Now we come to one of the biggest changes in human history — the Industrial Revolution. It started in England around 1760.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like looking at a map before we start our journey. See that long line? That's our timeline of history. We've already learned about other big times like the Enlightenment, and now we're going to place the Industrial Revolution right after it, starting way back around 1760 in a place called England. This was a time when everything started changing super fast!

slides.text: Describe life before: 'Imagine you live in 1700. Your family farms. Your mother spins thread and weaves cloth by hand. It takes days to make enough fabric for one shirt. Almost everything you use is made by hand in your village.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine living a long, long time ago, before any factories or even most machines! This slide wants you to picture that life: most people lived on farms, and if they needed clothes, they had to make the fabric themselves, by hand, which took many, many days. Everything you owned was made by hand, right there in your small village.

slides.text: Now introduce the change: 'People invented machines that could spin thread and weave cloth much faster than human hands. These machines were too big for homes, so they built factories — large buildings full of machines.' Show factory images.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is where the super exciting change happens! People invented amazing machines that could do the work of many hands, but much, much faster, especially for making things like thread and cloth. Because these machines were so big, they couldn't fit in homes, so people built huge buildings called factories to put them all in, and lots of workers came to use them.

slides.text: Pass around cotton. 'Feel this cotton. Before machines, turning this into thread took hours of hand-spinning. The spinning jenny could do the work of 8 spinners at once! The power loom could weave cloth 40 times faster than a person.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to feel history! Feel this piece of cotton – before machines, turning this fluff into thread to make clothes took hours and hours of work by hand. But then came inventions like the spinning jenny, which could do the work of eight people spinning at once, and the power loom, which could weave cloth super, super fast!

slides.prompt: Create a before-and-after illustration: On one side draw a family making cloth at home (spinning wheel, hand loom). On the other side draw a factory with machines and workers. Add a timeline entry for 'Industrial Revolution begins — 1760.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your chance to be an artist and show what you've learned! On one side of your paper, draw a picture of a family making cloth by hand at home, like with a spinning wheel. Then, on the other side, draw a big factory filled with machines and workers making things quickly. Don't forget to add a special note on your timeline entry saying the Industrial Revolution started around 1760!

slides.text: Discuss: 'How do you think people felt about these changes? What might be good about factories? What might be bad?' Save your thoughts — we'll explore more this week.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what the Industrial Revolution was and how factory production differed from hand production?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've just shown how life changed from making things slowly by hand on a farm to making things super fast with machines in factories during the Industrial Revolution. Think about how different that must have felt for people – it's amazing to imagine, isn't it? We'll discover even more cool stuff about this time later!

parent_notes: The Industrial Revolution is one of the most important turning points in history. At this age, focus on the concrete: what changed in daily life, how things were made differently, how fast things happened. Touch real cotton or wool to make it tangible. Over this week we'll also cover the harder aspects (child labor, pollution), but start with the wonder of innovation. The Montessori approach emphasizes helping children see connections — the Enlightenment's ideas about progress led directly to industrial innovation.

title: Geography of Industry — England's Coal and Iron
description: Students explore why the Industrial Revolution began in England by examining the geography of coal deposits, iron ore, and waterways that made industrialization possible.
instructions:
1. Show a map of England and Wales.
2. Locate the major coalfields: South Wales, Midlands, Yorkshire, Lancashire, Newcastle.
3. Discuss why coal was important: fuel for steam engines and iron smelting.
4. Locate iron ore deposits and show how they often overlap with coal regions.
5. Trace the rivers and canals that transported raw materials.
6. Have the child create a resource map of industrial England.
materials_needed: Map of England and Wales (blank and labeled)
Colored pencils (black for coal, red for iron, blue for waterways)
Piece of charcoal or coal (if available)

slides.heading: Geography of Industry
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn about how England's land, especially its coal and iron, helped it become a super important place during a time called the Industrial Revolution. Think of it like discovering a treasure map, but the treasure is why a whole country changed!

items: Blank map of England and Wales
slides.setup_instructions: Print a blank outline map of England and Wales. Have a reference map showing coalfields and iron deposits. If you have a piece of charcoal or coal, set it out for the child to examine.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need to make our own map of industrial England. We've got a blank map of England and Wales to draw on, a special map to help us see where everything is, and colorful pencils to mark it all down. We'll also use an atlas, which is like a book of maps, and maybe even a real piece of coal to see what it looks like up close!

slides.text: Ask: 'Why did the Industrial Revolution start in England and not somewhere else?' Show the map. 'The answer is partly in the ground beneath their feet. England had huge amounts of two things factories needed: coal and iron.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where our detective work begins! Imagine England is like a giant puzzle, and we need to figure out why the Industrial Revolution started *there*. This slide tells us the secret: it's all about what was hidden in the ground, like lots and lots of coal and iron, which were super important for making things.

slides.text: If you have coal or charcoal, let the child hold it. 'Coal is a black rock that burns very hot. It formed from ancient forests millions of years ago. England had enormous deposits of coal — some very close to the surface.' Color coalfields in black on the map: South Wales, the Midlands (Birmingham), Yorkshire, Lancashire (Manchester), and Newcastle.
slides.mascot_explanation: See this black stuff? It's coal! This slide explains that coal is like a special rock that burns really hot, and it was the perfect fuel for the new machines and factories that were being invented. England had tons of it, and we're going to mark all the places where they found it on our map using a black pencil.

slides.text: Add iron ore deposits in red. 'Iron ore is the rock that contains iron metal. When you heat iron ore with coal, you can melt out the iron to make machines, tools, bridges, and railways.' Show how coal and iron deposits often overlap.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're adding iron ore, which we'll color red. Iron is what strong things like tools, bridges, and even train tracks are made from! This slide points out that the best spots for finding iron ore were often right near the coal mines, which made it super easy for builders and inventors.

slides.text: Trace rivers and canals in blue. 'How did they move all this heavy coal and iron? By water! England's rivers and a new system of canals carried materials from mines to factories to ports.' Add key cities: London, Manchester, Birmingham, Liverpool, Newcastle.
slides.mascot_explanation: How did they move all those heavy rocks and metals? This slide shows us the answer: rivers and canals! They were like the highways of old England, carrying everything from the mines to the places where things were made, and then to the ships to be sent away. We'll draw these in blue on our map.

slides.prompt: Complete your resource map of industrial England. Include a color key (black = coal, red = iron, blue = waterways). Label at least 5 cities. Draw arrows showing how materials moved from mines to factories to ports.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's your turn to be the map maker! You're going to use all the information we've learned to create your very own resource map of England. Remember to use black for coal, red for iron, and blue for the waterways, and don't forget to label some of the important cities and show how things might have traveled around.

slides.text: Look at your finished map. 'England's natural resources — coal, iron, and waterways — gave it a huge advantage. Geography helped shape history!' Next time we'll see how railways changed everything.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why England's geography (coal, iron, waterways) helped start the Industrial Revolution?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that amazing map you made! You’ve shown exactly why England was such a great place for the Industrial Revolution to start, with all that coal, iron, and those helpful rivers and canals. You totally figured out how geography helped shape history – great job!

parent_notes: This lesson connects geography and history beautifully — a core Montessori principle. The key idea is that geography shapes human events. If you have actual coal or charcoal, letting the child handle it makes this concrete. Emphasize that these resources took millions of years to form (connecting to the first Great Lesson about Earth's formation). Maps at this age should be child-created, not just studied — the act of drawing encodes learning.

title: Read-Aloud: "The Lorax" by Dr. Seuss
description: Shared reading of Dr. Seuss's environmental fable about industrialization and its consequences, connecting to the week's Industrial Revolution theme.
instructions:
1. Introduce the book and author.
2. Read the story aloud with expression.
3. Pause at key moments to discuss: What is the Once-ler doing? Why does the Lorax speak for the trees?
4. After reading, discuss parallels to the Industrial Revolution.
5. Talk about the ending: 'Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It's not.'
6. Have the child respond in their reading journal.

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is showing us the title of our read-aloud story today. It's called "The Lorax," and it was written by a super fun author named Dr. Seuss! Have you ever read any of his books before? They're usually full of silly rhymes and amazing pictures.

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Set up a cozy reading area. Have the reading journal open to a fresh page.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now we need to get our reading supplies ready! We'll need the book "The Lorax," of course, and your reading journal and a pencil so you can write and draw. There are also colored pencils, which will be great for making your drawings extra special. Make sure you have all these things nearby, and maybe ask a grown-up to help you find a comfy spot to read!

slides.text: Before reading: 'This week we're learning about the Industrial Revolution — when people built factories and made lots of products with machines. This story by Dr. Seuss is about what can happen when someone builds a factory without thinking about the consequences.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is an important part before we even start reading. We've been learning about something called the Industrial Revolution, remember? That's when people started building lots of factories and making things with machines. Dr. Seuss wrote this story to show us what can happen when factories are built without thinking about how they might hurt nature.

slides.text: Read the story aloud. Use different voices for the Once-ler and the Lorax. Pause when the Once-ler builds his first factory: 'Does this remind you of what we learned about the Industrial Revolution?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, get ready for the story! I'm going to read "The Lorax" to you, and I want you to listen carefully. Try to imagine you're right there in the story! As we read, I'll pause and ask you some questions, like when the Once-ler starts building his factory. We'll think about if it reminds us of what we learned about the Industrial Revolution.

slides.text: After reading, discuss: 'What did the Once-ler want? What did the Lorax want? Were both of their wants reasonable? How could the Once-ler have made Thneeds without destroying the Truffula trees?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish the story, we're going to talk about what happened. We'll discuss what the Once-ler wanted and what the Lorax wanted, and if those things could have happened at the same time. It's like a puzzle – we'll figure out if the Once-ler could have made his "Thneeds" without hurting all the beautiful trees.

slides.prompt: In your reading journal, write a letter to the Once-ler. Give him advice about how he could run his factory while still protecting the environment. Use at least 3 complete sentences. Draw a picture of what a responsible Thneed factory might look like.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be creative! In your reading journal, you're going to write a letter to the Once-ler. Give him some advice on how he could run his factory without messing up the environment. Try to write at least three full sentences, and then draw a picture of what a factory that's kind to nature might look like. You have about 15 minutes to do this!

slides.text: Share your letters. Discuss the final message: 'Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It's not.' What can we do to care for our environment?
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify the conflict between industry and environment in the story and propose solutions?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did such a great job with your letters and drawings! Now we're going to share what we wrote and talk about the very last message in the book. It says that if we care about our planet, things can get better. What do you think we can do in our own lives to take care of the environment around us?

parent_notes: The Lorax is a perfect companion text for the Industrial Revolution unit. It presents complex themes (industrialization vs. environment, progress vs. conservation) in an accessible way. Avoid making it preachy — let the child form their own opinions. The letter-writing activity builds persuasive writing skills (previewing next week) while processing the story's themes. If your child is passionate about this topic, consider exploring what happened to England's forests during industrialization.

title: Journalism — Writing a News Lead
description: Students learn to write the most important part of a news article: the lead paragraph. They practice writing leads that answer the Five W's concisely.
instructions:
1. Review the Five W's from yesterday.
2. Explain the 'inverted pyramid' structure: most important info first.
3. Read 3-4 lead paragraphs from real articles and identify the W's in each.
4. Model writing a lead paragraph from a set of facts.
5. Give the child a set of facts and have them write their own lead.
6. Edit and revise together.

slides.heading: Journalism
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title for our lesson today! It tells us we're going to become super reporters and learn how to write the most important part of a news story, called a "lead." Think of it like the headline for your whole story!

slides.setup_instructions: Print 3-4 lead paragraphs from children's news sources. Create 2-3 'fact sheets' listing Who/What/When/Where/Why for fictional events. Draw an inverted pyramid showing 'Most Important' at top, 'Details' in middle, 'Background' at bottom.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's see what we need for our reporter mission! We have some sample news stories to read, some fact sheets that are like clues for our stories, a pencil and eraser for writing and fixing our work, a picture of an upside-down triangle, and a notebook. These are all the tools we need to become lead-writing pros!

slides.text: Review: 'Yesterday we learned the Five W's. Today we'll use them to write the lead — the very first paragraph of a news article. The lead is the most important part because many people only read the first paragraph!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember yesterday when we talked about the Five W's? That's Who, What, When, Where, and Why. Well, today we're going to use those W's to write the "lead," which is the very first sentence or two of a news story. It's super important because it tells readers the main idea right away!

slides.text: Show the inverted pyramid diagram. 'News articles are shaped like an upside-down triangle. The most important information goes at the very top. Details come next. Background information goes last. This is the opposite of a story, which saves the best for the end!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This picture shows us what news stories look like, kind of like an upside-down triangle. All the most important stuff, like who did what, goes right at the tippy-top. Then, as you go down the triangle, you get to the less important details. It's the opposite of a story where you save the exciting part for the end!

slides.text: Read sample leads together. For each one, underline the W's. Notice: 'A good lead answers at least 3-4 of the Five W's in just 1-2 sentences.' Point out how professional writers pack information tightly.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to read some real news leads, like a detective looking for clues! We'll read each one and find the Who, What, When, Where, and Why hiding inside. See how they pack lots of important information into just one or two sentences? That's what makes a great lead!

slides.text: Model writing a lead from facts: 'WHO: Students at Oak Elementary. WHAT: Raised $500 for animal shelter. WHEN: Last Friday. WHERE: School gymnasium. WHY: Wanted to help homeless pets.' Write together: 'Students at Oak Elementary raised $500 for the local animal shelter during a fundraiser in the school gymnasium last Friday.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch closely as I show you how to build a lead! We have some facts here about students raising money. I'll take those facts – who did it, what they did, when and where it happened, and why – and weave them together into a clear first sentence. It's like putting puzzle pieces together to make a picture!

slides.prompt: Use the fact sheet to write your own lead paragraph. Remember: answer at least 3 of the Five W's in 1-2 sentences. Put the most important information first. Write two different leads for the same facts — which one sounds better?
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's your turn to be the reporter! You've got a fact sheet with all the clues, and your job is to write your own news lead using those facts. Try to answer at least three of the Five W's in just one or two sentences, and remember to put the most important info first. You can even try writing two different leads and pick your favorite!

slides.text: Read your leads aloud. Check: Did you answer the Five W's? Is the most important info first? Is it clear and concise? Save your best leads — you'll use this skill for your class newspaper!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a clear lead paragraph that answers at least 3 of the 5 W's?
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job, super reporter! Let's read the leads you wrote out loud and check them together. Did you get at least three W's in there? Is the most important stuff right at the beginning? You've learned how to write a news lead, which is a really cool skill, especially for our class newspaper!

parent_notes: The lead paragraph is the hardest part of news writing because it requires the child to prioritize information — a higher-order thinking skill. Don't worry about perfection; focus on getting the W's in and making it clear. Having the child write two versions of the same lead is a powerful revision technique. You can create fact sheets from events in your own life: a family trip, a pet's birthday, a neighborhood event.

title: Data and Graphing — Creating Bar Graphs
description: Students learn to create their own bar graphs from data sets, choosing appropriate scales and labels to represent information accurately.
instructions:
1. Review bar graph components from yesterday.
2. Present a data table (e.g., favorite animals survey).
3. Model how to choose a scale, draw axes, label categories.
4. Demonstrate drawing bars to the correct height.
5. Add a title.
6. Have the child create a bar graph from a new data set independently.

slides.heading: Data and Graphing
slides.mascot_explanation: Hey there! This first slide tells us what we're going to be experts at today: making bar graphs! Think of bar graphs like a super cool way to turn lists of numbers into a picture so we can understand things way faster, just like how a picture of a yummy cake tells you more than just words!

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 2-3 simple data tables with 4-6 categories and values under 20. Example: 'Books Read This Month: Fiction-8, Science-5, History-3, Biography-6, Poetry-4.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, let's get our tools ready for some graphing fun! We've got graph paper for drawing our big picture, a ruler to make super straight lines, a pencil for all our drawing, and colored pencils to make our graphs pop! We also have some data tables, which are just lists of information, and an eraser in case we need to fix any oopsies. Make sure you have all these things handy!

slides.text: Review: 'Yesterday we read bar graphs. Today we'll make our own! A bar graph turns a boring table of numbers into a picture that makes data easy to understand.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember yesterday when we looked at those bar graphs? Well, today we get to be the artists and build our very own! A bar graph is like a secret code that turns boring numbers into an easy-to-see picture, making it simple to compare things. It’s like turning a list of your favorite toys into a drawing so you can see which one you have the most of!

slides.text: Show the first data table. 'Step 1: Look at the largest number. That tells us how high our graph needs to go. Step 2: Choose a scale — counting by 1s, 2s, or 5s. Step 3: Draw the y-axis (vertical line with numbers) and x-axis (horizontal line with categories).'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, for this step, we're going to get our graph ready to draw. First, we look at our list of numbers and find the biggest one – that tells us how tall our graph needs to be. Then, we decide if we want to count by 1s, 2s, or maybe 5s for our numbers on the side. Finally, we draw two lines, one going straight up like a tall building and one going across like a road, and we'll add our numbers and the names of our things.

slides.text: Model drawing the graph together. Use the ruler to draw straight lines. 'Each bar should be the same width with equal spaces between them. Use the scale on the y-axis to make each bar the correct height. Color each bar.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the really fun part – drawing the bars! We'll use our ruler to make sure each bar is the same width and has enough space between them, just like building with LEGOs. Then, we'll use the numbers on our side line to make each bar exactly the right height, so they show our information perfectly, and we can color them in to make them extra special!

slides.text: Add the title and labels. 'A graph without a title is like a book without a cover — no one knows what it's about! The title should tell the reader exactly what data is shown.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like giving our graph a name tag! We need to add a title at the very top, which tells everyone exactly what information our graph is showing, like "Our Favorite Ice Cream Flavors." Without a title, our graph is like a mystery, and nobody will know what awesome information we've collected!

slides.prompt: Create your own bar graph from the second data table. Follow the steps: 1) Find the highest value, 2) Choose a scale, 3) Draw and label axes, 4) Draw bars, 5) Color and add a title. Then write 3 sentences describing what your graph shows.
slides.mascot_explanation: Woohoo, it's your turn to be the graph-making superstar! You'll use the new list of information to create your very own bar graph, following all the steps we just learned: find the biggest number, pick how you'll count, draw your lines, make your bars the right height, color them in, and give it a great title. Then, write three sentences telling me what your graph shows us!

slides.text: Check your graph: Are bars the correct height? Are labels clear? Is there a title? Trade graphs with a partner (or parent) — can they read your graph correctly?
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create an accurate, labeled bar graph from a data table with an appropriate scale?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's check out your amazing graph! Look closely: are your bars the right height compared to the numbers? Are all the words and labels easy to read? And is the title super clear? Now, if you can, trade your graph with someone else so they can tell you what it shows – that's how we know it's a great graph!

parent_notes: Creating graphs is harder than reading them — it requires the child to make decisions about scale, spacing, and design. Graph paper is essential for keeping bars even. Common mistakes: choosing a scale that's too large (bars too short to read) or too small (bars go off the page), uneven bar widths, and forgetting labels. Let the child discover these problems rather than preventing them. Surveys of family members or friends make engaging data sources.

title: Habitats and Biomes — What Is a Biome?
description: Students explore the concept of biomes — large regions of the world with similar climate, plants, and animals. They learn the six major biomes and their key characteristics.
instructions:
1. Review ecosystems and habitats from previous ecology lessons.
2. Introduce the concept of a biome: a large area with similar climate, plants, and animals.
3. Present the six major biomes: tropical rainforest, desert, grassland, temperate forest, taiga, tundra.
4. Show images of each biome and discuss temperature, rainfall, plants, and animals.
5. Begin a biome comparison chart.
6. Start a biome booklet that will be completed over the week.
materials_needed: Photos of each biome (printed or digital)

slides.heading: Habitats and Biomes
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure! It tells us we're going to learn all about "Habitats and Biomes" and, most importantly, what a biome is. Think of it as the big introduction to a super interesting story about our amazing planet!

slides.setup_instructions: Print a world map colored by biome. Gather clear photos of each biome showing landscape, plants, and animals. Create a chart template with columns: Biome, Climate, Temperature, Rainfall, Key Plants, Key Animals.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our explorer gear ready! We need a big map that shows all the biomes on Earth, some pictures that show us what each biome looks like with its plants and animals, a special chart to help us compare them, some colorful paper to make our own biome books, and colored pencils to draw, plus a stapler to put it all together. You'll need a grown-up to help you find and gather all these things.

slides.text: Review: 'We've studied habitats — places where animals live. A habitat can be as small as a pond. Today we're going bigger — much bigger. A biome is a huge region of Earth with similar weather, plants, and animals. Think of it as a super-habitat.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how we learned that a habitat is like a home for animals, like a pond or a forest? Well, a biome is like a giant, super-habitat! It’s a huge area on Earth that shares the same kind of weather, like how much rain falls and how warm or cold it is, and the same kinds of plants and animals live there.

slides.text: Show the world biome map. 'Earth has six major biomes. Notice how they form bands across the globe — that's because biomes depend on climate, and climate depends on where you are relative to the equator.' Point out the equator and poles.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, look at this cool map of the world! It shows us where all the different biomes are. See how they make big stripes across the Earth? That’s because the weather, or climate, changes the farther you get from the warm middle part of the Earth (that's the equator!) and the closer you get to the cold top and bottom (those are the poles!).

slides.text: Introduce each biome with photos: Tropical Rainforest (hot, wet, most species), Desert (hot or cold, very dry), Grassland (moderate, grasses dominate), Temperate Forest (four seasons, deciduous trees), Taiga (cold, coniferous forests), Tundra (coldest, no trees).
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to meet some amazing places! We're going to see pictures of six main biomes: the super-hot and rainy tropical rainforest, the dry desert, the grassy grasslands, the forests with trees that lose their leaves in the fall (temperate forests), the chilly forests with pointy trees (taiga), and the very, very cold tundra where hardly anything grows.

slides.text: Begin filling in the comparison chart together for 2-3 biomes. 'Let's compare the tropical rainforest and the tundra — they're opposites! The rainforest gets over 80 inches of rain per year; the tundra gets less than 10.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we become super scientists and compare these awesome places! We'll start filling out a chart to write down what the weather is like, how much rain or snow falls, and what plants and animals live in each biome. We'll even compare the super wet rainforest to the very dry tundra to see how different they are!

slides.prompt: Start your biome booklet: fold construction paper to make a 6-page booklet (one page per biome). On the first page, write 'My Biome Booklet' with your name. On page 2, draw and label the tropical rainforest with at least 3 plants and 3 animals. Complete the comparison chart for all 6 biomes.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to create your very own biome book! Take your paper, fold it to make six pages, and write "My Biome Booklet" on the front with your name. Then, on the next page, draw the tropical rainforest and add at least three plants and three animals you'd find there. Keep filling in the pages for all the biomes as we learn about them, and don't forget to finish filling in our comparison chart too!

slides.text: Look at the biome map one more time. 'Which biome do we live in? How do you know?' We'll explore more biomes in detail throughout the week.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name the six major biomes and describe at least two key characteristics of each?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's take one last look at our big biome map. Can you guess which biome we live in right here? Think about our weather and the plants and animals around us to help you figure it out! You've done a fantastic job learning about all six biomes and comparing them today!

parent_notes: Biomes connect geography and science beautifully. The key concept is that climate (temperature and rainfall) determines what can live in an area. Don't require memorization of all details — the comparison chart and booklet are reference tools. If possible, watch short video clips of each biome to make it vivid. A simple biome can be created in a jar (terrarium) if the child is inspired. Connect to your local biome: 'Which biome do we live in? What evidence do you see?'

title: Art of Industry — Factory Landscapes and L.S. Lowry
description: Students study the industrial landscape paintings of L.S. Lowry, exploring how art documented the Industrial Revolution. They create their own factory town scene inspired by Lowry's style.
instructions:
1. Show reproductions of L.S. Lowry's industrial paintings.
2. Discuss what they see: smokestacks, factories, crowds of small figures, grey skies.
3. Connect to the Industrial Revolution history lesson.
4. Analyze Lowry's style: simple stick-like figures, muted colors, towering buildings.
5. Demonstrate painting a simple factory scene using Lowry's techniques.
6. Have the child create their own industrial landscape.

slides.heading: Art of Industry
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of our art adventure! It tells us we're going to learn about "Art of Industry," which is all about how artists painted pictures of big factories and towns, especially from a time called the Industrial Revolution, and we'll be looking at the work of an artist named L.S. Lowry.

slides.setup_instructions: Print 3-4 Lowry paintings: 'Coming from the Mill,' 'Industrial Landscape,' and 'Going to the Match.' Set up a painting station with watercolors, water cup, and thick paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool stuff we'll need for our art project! We've got pictures of paintings by L.S. Lowry to look at, watercolors to paint with, nice thick paper, paintbrushes for details and bigger strokes, a cup of water to clean our brushes, paper towels for drying them, and a black marker for adding the finishing touches. Can you help a grown-up gather all these supplies?

slides.text: Show Lowry's paintings. 'This artist, L.S. Lowry, lived in Manchester, England — one of the biggest factory cities during the Industrial Revolution. He painted what he saw every day: factories, smokestacks, and crowds of workers.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to see some real paintings by L.S. Lowry! He was an artist who lived a long, long time ago when lots of big factories were being built, and he loved to paint what he saw. Look closely – he painted tall buildings with smokestacks puffing out smoke, and lots and lots of tiny people walking around.

slides.text: Study the paintings closely. 'What colors do you see? (Greys, browns, muted tones — the smoky air!) What are the people doing? (Walking to work, leaving factories.) How big are the people compared to the buildings? (Tiny! The factories dominate.)'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look super closely at these paintings. What colors do you notice? Lowry mostly used grays and browns, right? That's because the factories made so much smoke, the sky often looked hazy and dull. See how small the people are compared to the giant buildings? They look like they're all going to work.

slides.text: Point out Lowry's techniques: 'His people look like matchstick figures — simple lines for bodies, arms, and legs. He painted hundreds of them to show the crowds. His buildings are simple rectangles with smokestacks. The sky is always grey or pale.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's talk about *how* Lowry painted. Look at the people – they're drawn with just simple lines, like little matchsticks! He would paint hundreds of them to show how many workers there were. And his buildings are just basic shapes, like rectangles, with tall smokestacks on top, and the sky is usually a pale gray.

slides.text: Demonstrate: Wash the paper with a grey/blue sky. While wet, add darker grey at the bottom for ground. Once dry, paint simple rectangular factory buildings with smokestacks. Add tiny matchstick people walking along the street.
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide shows us how to start painting our own factory picture, just like Lowry! First, we'll wash our paper with some gray and blue paint for the sky, and then add some darker gray at the bottom for the ground while it's still wet. Once that's dry, we'll paint simple buildings with smokestacks and then add tiny matchstick people walking around.

slides.prompt: Create your own Lowry-inspired factory town painting. Include: grey/blue sky, at least 3 factory buildings with smokestacks (add smoke!), a street, and at least 10 matchstick people. Use muted colors. Add details with black marker when dry.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your chance to be the artist! You get to create your very own factory town, inspired by L.S. Lowry. Make sure you paint a sky, at least three factory buildings with smoke coming out, a street, and at least ten little matchstick people. Use those muted colors we saw, and when your painting is dry, you can use the black marker to add extra details. You've got this!

slides.text: Display your painting. 'How does your factory town feel? Is it a cheerful place or a gloomy one? Lowry said he painted the sadness and beauty he saw in industrial life. Art can show us what life was really like in the past.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe Lowry's artistic style and create a factory landscape using his techniques?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the amazing factory town you created! It's so cool how you used those muted colors and drew all those little people, just like L.S. Lowry. Think about how your painting makes you feel – is it a busy place? Maybe a little bit sad or maybe even beautiful in its own way? You did a fantastic job showing us what industrial life might have looked like!

parent_notes: Lowry is an accessible artist for children because his matchstick-figure style is approachable — children don't feel intimidated by it. The real learning is in observing and discussing: What story does the painting tell? How does the art make you feel? This connects art to history and develops visual literacy. If you can't print Lowry's work, search online and view on screen. Emphasize that art is a primary source — it tells us about the past just like a history book.

title: From Raw Materials to Products — Making Butter
description: Students experience the transformation of a raw material (cream) into a finished product (butter) by hand, connecting to the Industrial Revolution theme of manufacturing and the difference between handmade and factory-made goods.
instructions:
1. Show heavy cream in a jar. Ask: 'What is butter made from? How do you think people made butter before factories?'
2. Explain that for thousands of years, butter was made by hand — churning cream.
3. Pour heavy cream into a jar, seal tightly.
4. Shake vigorously! Take turns. It will take 10-15 minutes.
5. Observe the stages: cream → whipped cream → butter + buttermilk.
6. Strain, rinse with cold water, add salt.
7. Taste on bread. Discuss: handmade vs. factory-made.
materials_needed: Clean glass jar with tight lid

slides.heading: From Raw Materials to Products
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is showing us the big idea for our activity today: turning something simple, like cream, into something yummy, like butter! We're going to learn how people used to make it all by themselves before big factories existed.

slides.setup_instructions: Take heavy cream out of the fridge 30 minutes before the lesson. Fill the jar only halfway with cream (it needs room to slosh). Have bread ready for tasting at the end.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready! We need heavy cream, which is like super-rich milk; a glass jar with a lid that closes really tight so nothing spills; a strainer that looks like a little net; cold water; a tiny bit of salt; bread or crackers to eat our butter on; a knife to spread it; a bowl to put things in; and a timer to see how long it takes. Go grab everything with a grown-up!

slides.text: Show the cream. 'This is heavy cream — it comes from cow's milk. For thousands of years, people turned cream into butter using only their hands and a churn. Before the Industrial Revolution, every family had to make their own butter. Today, machines in factories make millions of pounds of butter a day.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our starting ingredient: heavy cream! It comes from cows and is super creamy. Long ago, before machines, people would shake or churn cream to make butter. Imagine having to do that all by yourself every single day to have butter for your toast!

slides.text: Pour cream into the jar (halfway full). Seal tightly. 'We're going to make butter the old-fashioned way — by shaking! This is basically what a butter churn does. We'll time how long it takes.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pour the heavy cream into our jar. We don't want to fill it up too much, just about halfway, because the cream needs room to move around when we shake it. Then, we'll put the lid on super tight so it doesn't pop off!

slides.text: Start shaking! Set the timer. 'Shake it hard and steady. Listen — can you hear the cream sloshing? After a few minutes, it will get quiet — that means it turned into whipped cream. Keep shaking! Eventually you'll hear a THUNK — that's butter!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to shake, shake, shake! This is how we turn the cream into butter, just like people did a long, long time ago. Keep shaking steadily, and after a while, you'll notice the cream changes from runny to fluffy like whipped cream, and then suddenly, you'll feel a change and hear a little 'thunk' – that means the butter has formed!

slides.text: When butter forms (10-15 minutes of shaking): 'Open the jar carefully. See the solid lump? That's butter! The liquid left over is buttermilk.' Strain out the buttermilk. Rinse the butter with cold water and add a pinch of salt.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! We've made butter! See that solid yellow stuff? That's our butter, and the watery stuff left behind is called buttermilk. We'll carefully pour out the buttermilk using our strainer, then rinse the butter with cold water and add a little salt to make it taste just right.

slides.prompt: Spread your homemade butter on bread and taste it. In your notebook, answer: How long did it take to make butter by hand? How would your arms feel if you had to make butter every day? Why was the invention of factory machines so important to families?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the best part – tasting our creation! Spread your homemade butter on the bread or crackers. Think about how long it took us to make this. Can you imagine having to shake a jar for 15 minutes every single time you wanted butter? That's why new machines were such a big deal!

slides.text: Compare: 'A factory can make in one minute what took us 15 minutes. Imagine making butter for a whole village! Now you understand why the Industrial Revolution changed everything.' Clean up all materials together.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child describe the process of making butter and explain why factory manufacturing was a significant change?
slides.mascot_explanation: See how quickly factories can make tons of butter compared to our 15 minutes? It's amazing how making things by hand helped people understand why machines and factories were invented during the Industrial Revolution. Great job making butter today!

parent_notes: This is a powerful experiential lesson. The child literally feels the effort of pre-industrial manufacturing. The key insight comes after shaking for 10+ minutes: 'My arms are tired!' That's the point — before machines, every product required enormous human effort. Use this as a springboard: 'What other things do you eat that used to be made entirely by hand?' Cream at room temperature works faster. The jar should be only half full. If cream is too cold, it may take 20+ minutes.

title: Journalism — Interviewing and Quoting Sources
description: Students learn how journalists gather information through interviews and use direct quotes in their articles. They practice writing interview questions and conducting a mock interview.
instructions:
1. Discuss: 'How do reporters know what happened? They ask people!'
2. Introduce the concept of a source — someone who has firsthand knowledge.
3. Teach the difference between direct quotes and paraphrasing.
4. Model writing good interview questions (open-ended, not yes/no).
5. Have the child write 5 interview questions.
6. Conduct a mock interview with a family member.
7. Practice writing sentences with direct quotes and correct punctuation.
materials_needed: Sample news article with quotes highlighted

slides.heading: Journalism
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our adventure today! It tells us we're going to become super reporters and learn all about how journalists get their stories by talking to people and using their exact words. It's like being a detective for news!

items: Sample news article with quotes highlighted
List of question starters (Who, What, When, Where, Why, How, Can you describe, Tell me about)
slides.setup_instructions: Highlight direct quotes in a sample article before the lesson. Prepare a list of open-ended question starters. Arrange for a family member to be available for a practice interview.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the cool tools we'll need for our reporter training! We have a notebook and pencil to write things down, a sample news article that already has some special sentences marked, and a list of words that help us ask great questions. We also have a clipboard to hold our papers, and we'll need a grown-up to help us find these things and make sure we have someone to interview later!

slides.text: Read a news article with quotes highlighted. 'See these sentences in quotation marks? These are the exact words someone said. They're called direct quotes. Reporters include quotes to let readers hear from real people — it makes the story believable and interesting.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This step is like looking at a secret code! See those funny little marks around some sentences in the article? Those are called quotation marks, and they show us the *exact* words someone said. Reporters use these "direct quotes" to make their stories feel super real, like you're right there hearing it yourself!

slides.text: Explain sources: 'A source is someone who knows about the event. If there was a school fundraiser, the sources might be the teacher who organized it, a student who participated, and a parent who donated.' Good reporters talk to multiple sources.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's talk about who reporters talk to! They talk to "sources," which are just people who really know what happened. Think about it: if your toy broke, your source would be the person who saw it happen, not someone who just heard about it. Good reporters talk to lots of different sources to get the whole story!

slides.text: Teach interview questions. 'Bad question: Did you like the event? (Yes/No — boring!) Good question: What was the best part of the event? (This gets a detailed, quotable answer!)' Practice turning closed questions into open ones.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we learn to ask questions like a pro! A yucky question is one you can just answer "yes" or "no" to, like "Were you happy?" That's boring! A super reporter asks questions that start with words like "Who," "What," "When," "Where," "Why," or "How," because those get people talking and sharing awesome details!

slides.text: Review quotation mark rules: 'Quotation marks go around the person's exact words. A comma separates the quote from who said it. Example: "The fundraiser was amazing," said Mrs. Johnson. Or: Mrs. Johnson said, "The fundraiser was amazing."'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to practice putting those quotation marks in the right spots! It's like putting little hugs around the words someone said. Remember, you need a comma to tell the reader who is talking, and then the quotation marks go right around their exact words. We'll look at examples to get it just right!

slides.prompt: Write 5 open-ended interview questions about a topic (a family member's favorite hobby, their job, or a family tradition). Then conduct a real interview! Write down the answers. Select the two best quotes and write them correctly with quotation marks.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the exciting part where you get to be the reporter! You'll think of five great questions about something your family member likes, then you'll interview them and write down their answers. After that, pick the two most interesting answers, called quotes, and write them down perfectly using those quotation marks we learned about!

slides.text: Read your quotes aloud. Check: Are quotation marks in the right place? Did you identify who said it? You now have real reporting skills! These quotes could go into a news article.
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write open-ended interview questions, conduct a brief interview, and correctly punctuate direct quotes?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You asked questions, listened carefully, and even wrote down real quotes with the right punctuation. Reading those quotes aloud shows everyone you're a fantastic reporter, just like the ones on TV or in the newspaper. You learned how to find and share people's stories today!

parent_notes: Being interviewed is a wonderful opportunity for family connection. The child gets to practice active listening, note-taking, and writing skills simultaneously. When being interviewed, give detailed answers that are quotable — not just one-word responses. Modeling enthusiasm for the interview process teaches the child that everyone's story matters. Quotation punctuation is genuinely tricky — expect mistakes and correct gently over time.

title: Data and Graphing — Line Graphs
description: Students learn to read and create line graphs, understanding that line graphs show change over time. They compare line graphs to bar graphs and determine when each type is appropriate.
instructions:
1. Show a line graph (e.g., temperature over a week).
2. Explain: line graphs show how something changes over time.
3. Identify parts: title, x-axis (time), y-axis (values), data points, lines connecting them.
4. Practice reading values and identifying trends (going up, going down, staying the same).
5. Compare: When do you use a bar graph vs. a line graph?
6. Have the child create a line graph from data.
materials_needed: Data table for temperature or plant growth

slides.heading: Data and Graphing
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is like the cover of our book for today! It tells us we're going to learn all about "Data and Graphing," and our special focus will be on "Line Graphs." It's like we're becoming detectives for information!

items: Data table (temperature or plant growth over time)
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare sample line graphs at different difficulty levels. Create a data table showing daily temperatures for a week or plant growth measured daily for 10 days.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our detective tools ready! We have some example line graphs to look at, some graph paper to draw on, a ruler to make straight lines, and a pencil. We also have a special chart with numbers, maybe about how warm it was each day or how tall a plant grew, and some colored pencils to make our graphs look super neat. Go find a grown-up to help you gather all these things!

slides.text: Show the first line graph. 'This graph looks different from bar graphs. Instead of bars, we have dots connected by lines. A line graph is special — it shows how something changes over time. The x-axis shows time (days, weeks, months) and the y-axis shows the value being measured.'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, what we're looking at here is our first line graph. See how it's not made of chunky bars like some graphs we've seen? Instead, it has little dots that are connected by lines. This kind of graph is super helpful because it shows us how something changes as time passes, like maybe the temperature going up and down throughout the week. The bottom line, called the x-axis, shows us the time, and the side line, called the y-axis, shows us the numbers.

slides.text: Read the graph together. 'Find Monday — put your finger on it. Now go straight up to the line. Now go straight left to the y-axis. What was the temperature on Monday?' Practice with each day. 'Which day was warmest? Coldest?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pretend this graph is about the weather! Find "Monday" on the bottom. Put your finger right on it, and then trace your finger straight up until you hit the line. Now, move your finger straight over to the side line, the y-axis, and see what number it points to – that tells us how warm it was on Monday! We can do this for every day to see what happened.

slides.text: Introduce trends: 'When the line goes up, the value is increasing. When it goes down, it's decreasing. When it's flat, it's staying the same. We can see patterns — like it got warmer from Monday to Wednesday, then cooler again.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at how the line is moving! When the line goes up, it means whatever we're measuring is getting bigger or hotter, like a rocket going to space! If the line goes down, it's getting smaller or colder. And if it stays flat, it means it's not changing at all. We can spot patterns, like maybe it got warmer for a few days and then cooler again.

slides.text: Compare graph types: 'Bar graphs compare different categories (favorite flavors, number of pets). Line graphs show change over TIME. Ask yourself: Does my data show change over time? If yes → line graph. If it compares categories → bar graph.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember those bar graphs we used to show favorite ice cream flavors? Those are great for comparing different things. But if we want to see how something *changes* over time, like how a plant grows taller each day or how the temperature changes through the week, a line graph is the best tool! It helps us see the story of change.

slides.prompt: Create a line graph from the data table. Steps: 1) Draw and label axes (time on x-axis, values on y-axis). 2) Choose an appropriate scale. 3) Plot each data point as a dot. 4) Connect the dots with straight lines. 5) Add a title. Then describe the trend in 2-3 sentences.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, time to make our own line graph detective masterpiece! We'll use the numbers from our chart to draw the bottom line for time and the side line for the measurements, making sure to label them. Then, we'll carefully put a dot for each day's number and connect them with straight lines to show the story of how things changed. Finally, we'll give our graph a title and write a couple of sentences about what the line is telling us. You've got this!

slides.text: Look at your line graph. 'What trend do you see? Is the line generally going up, going down, or staying about the same?' Discuss why being able to see trends is useful in real life (weather, stock markets, sports statistics).
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read a line graph, identify trends, create one from data, and explain when to use a line graph vs. a bar graph?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at the amazing line graph you created! You followed all the steps and made a picture that tells a story about how things changed over time. Being able to see these patterns, like whether things are going up or down, helps us understand the world better, just like real scientists do when they study the weather or how animals grow. You're a graphing superstar!

parent_notes: Line graphs are conceptually harder than bar graphs because they require understanding continuous change. The connection between dots implies that change happened gradually between data points. Start with relatable data — weather is ideal because children can verify it themselves. A fun extension: have the child record the daily temperature for a week and graph it. Real data collection makes graphing meaningful rather than abstract.

title: The Steam Engine — Power That Changed the World
description: Students learn about James Watt's improvement of the steam engine and how steam power transformed manufacturing, transportation, and daily life during the Industrial Revolution.
instructions:
1. Review: factories needed power to run machines. Before steam, they used water wheels.
2. Introduce James Watt and his improved steam engine (1769).
3. Explain how a steam engine works in simple terms: heat water → steam → pushes a piston → drives machines.
4. Discuss what steam engines powered: factory machines, trains, ships.
5. Do a simple steam demonstration (kettle or pot with lid).
6. Add to the Industrial Revolution timeline.
materials_needed: Pictures of James Watt and steam engines
Simple diagram of a steam engine

slides.heading: The Steam Engine
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the cover of a book, and it's telling us we're going to learn about something super important called the steam engine! It even says it's "Power That Changed the World," which sounds really exciting, doesn't it? We're going to find out why it was so powerful.

items: Pictures of James Watt and steam engines
slides.setup_instructions: Print a diagram showing how a steam engine works (boiler, piston, cylinder). Have a kettle ready to boil water for a safe steam demonstration. Set up the timeline from Monday.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this slide shows us all the things we need for our adventure into steam power! We've got pictures of James Watt and some cool-looking steam engines, a drawing that helps us see inside them, and a kettle or pot. We also need some paper, pencils, and things to make a timeline. Make sure you ask a grown-up to help you gather all these materials!

slides.text: Review: 'We learned that factories had big machines. But what made those machines move? At first, factories had to be built next to rivers because they used water wheels for power. That limited where you could build a factory.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is like a quick reminder of what we learned before. Remember how factories had lots of noisy machines? Well, at first, those machines needed to be right next to rivers because they used giant water wheels to get their power. That meant factories could only be built in a few special spots!

slides.text: Introduce Watt: 'A Scottish inventor named James Watt didn't invent the steam engine, but he made it much better in 1769. His improved engine was powerful, efficient, and reliable. It changed everything.' Show his portrait.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's meet a very clever inventor named James Watt! He didn't invent the steam engine all by himself, but he made it way, way better around the year 1769. His improvements made the steam engine super strong and reliable, and that's what really helped to change how things were made and how people traveled.

slides.text: Explain how it works with the diagram: 'You heat water in a boiler until it becomes steam. Steam takes up much more space than water — it expands with force! That force pushes a piston back and forth. The piston turns a wheel. The wheel powers the machines.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This diagram is like a secret map showing how the steam engine works its magic! You heat water until it turns into steam, and steam is like a super-powered puff of air that pushes things. That push moves a special part called a piston, which then makes a wheel spin and spin to power all sorts of machines. Isn't it amazing how steam can do so much work?

slides.text: Demonstrate with a kettle (adult supervision). Boil water and watch the steam push the lid. 'See how the steam lifts the lid? Now imagine that force pushing a metal piston inside a cylinder — that's a steam engine! This tiny amount of steam moved the lid. Imagine a giant boiler!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time for a cool experiment with a grown-up's help! See this kettle? When we boil water, it makes steam, and that steam can actually push the lid up a little bit. Imagine that same power, but inside a big metal machine, pushing a piston really hard to make huge wheels turn! It shows you just how strong that invisible steam can be.

slides.prompt: Draw a diagram of how a steam engine works with labels: boiler, water, fire, steam, piston, wheel. Then write 3 things the steam engine made possible that weren't possible before (factories anywhere, trains, steamships). Add James Watt and the steam engine to your timeline.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to be the inventor and artist! Grab your paper and pencils and draw your own diagram of how the steam engine works, remembering to label the boiler, water, fire, steam, piston, and wheel. Then, think about three big things that steam engines made possible, like building factories anywhere or creating fast trains and ships, and add them to your timeline!

slides.text: The steam engine is one of the most important inventions in history. Before steam, everything depended on muscle power, water power, or wind. 'Can you imagine a world without engines? What would be different in your daily life?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain how a steam engine works in basic terms and describe at least 3 ways it changed the world?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we've learned all about the amazing steam engine today! It's one of the most important inventions ever because it gave us so much power, unlike anything before. Think about it: could you imagine your world without engines in cars or buses? You did a fantastic job understanding how it works and how it changed everything!

parent_notes: The steam demonstration with a kettle is safe and powerful — always supervise closely. The key concept is energy transformation: chemical energy (burning coal) → heat energy (boiling water) → kinetic energy (steam pushing piston) → mechanical energy (turning wheels). You don't need to use these terms, but the concept of one form of energy becoming another is foundational. James Watt's name gives us the 'watt' — the unit of power. Older children may enjoy learning this connection.

title: Life in an Industrial City — Workers and Their Families
description: Students explore daily life in an industrial city, learning about the living and working conditions of factory workers and their families, including the role of child labor.
instructions:
1. Describe what industrial cities looked like: crowded, smoky, noisy.
2. Compare village life vs. city life for workers.
3. Discuss working conditions: 12-16 hour days, dangerous machines, low pay.
4. Introduce child labor — children as young as 5 worked in factories and mines.
5. Read primary source excerpts (adapted) about child workers.
6. Discuss feelings and fairness.
7. Introduce reformers who fought to change these conditions.
materials_needed: Adapted primary source excerpts about child labor
Comparison chart template (village life vs. city life)

slides.heading: Life in an Industrial City
slides.mascot_explanation: This slide is the title of our lesson, showing us that we're going to learn all about what life was like for families living in big cities when factories first started opening up a long, long time ago. It's like a sneak peek into a whole new world!

items: Comparison chart (village life vs. city life)
slides.setup_instructions: Print images of 19th-century industrial cities (factories, tenements, child workers). Prepare adapted excerpts from parliamentary reports on child labor. Create a comparison chart template.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for this adventure! We have pictures showing what those old cities looked like, some stories from kids who lived back then, a chart to compare village life and city life, and then some paper and pencils for drawing our own ideas. You'll need a grown-up to help you gather everything.

slides.text: Show pictures of industrial cities. 'When factories opened, people moved from villages to cities for work. Thousands of families crowded into tiny apartments near the factories. The air was thick with smoke. The streets were dirty. The rivers were polluted.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these pictures! See how crowded and smoky everything is? When factories started, tons of people left their quiet villages to find jobs in these huge cities, but it meant living in tiny, packed apartments with dirty air and streets. Imagine living where you can barely see the sun because of all the smoke!

slides.text: Fill in the comparison chart together. Village Life: fresh air, grew own food, knew neighbors, worked sunrise to sunset outdoors. City Life: smoky air, bought food (often poor quality), crowded tenements, worked 12-16 hours indoors.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to fill out this chart comparing life in a village to life in the city. In villages, people had fresh air and grew their own food, but in the city, the air was yucky, food was hard to get, and everyone lived super close together, working super long hours inside. It's a big difference, isn't it?

slides.text: Discuss child labor sensitively: 'Many families were so poor that even children had to work. Children as young as 5 or 6 worked in factories and coal mines. They did dangerous jobs because they were small enough to crawl under machines or into narrow mine tunnels.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part is about child labor, and it's important to understand it was a really sad time. Because families didn't have much money, even very young kids, sometimes as young as 5, had to work in factories or deep in mines doing dangerous jobs. They were small enough to fit into tight spots where adults couldn't go.

slides.text: Read an adapted excerpt. Example: 'I go to work at 5 in the morning. I don't stop until 8 at night. I get one break for lunch. My job is to crawl under the spinning machines and sweep the cotton dust. Sometimes I'm so tired I can't stay awake.' Discuss: How does this make you feel? Is this fair?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to read a story from a child who actually worked in a factory. Listen carefully to what they say about waking up super early, working all day, and doing a tough job. Think about how you would feel if that was your life and if it seems fair.

slides.prompt: Write a diary entry from the perspective of a child factory worker in the 1800s. Describe your day: When do you wake up? What is your job? What do you eat? How do you feel? Then write 2-3 sentences about what you think should change.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a detective from the past! Imagine you are a child working in a factory a long time ago.
